title: 104_hr1434
content: The joint resolution authorizes the United States Trade Representative to negotiate amendments to the rules and procedures of the Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes. The joint resolution authorizes the United States Trade Representative to negotiate amendments to the rules and procedures of the Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes, based on the affirmative report submitted to Congress by the WTO Dispute Settlement Review Commission. The joint resolution authorizes the US Trade Representative to negotiate amendments to WTO rules and procedures. If negotiations fail to result in a satisfactory solution, Congress can withdraw its approval of the WTO Agreement. The procedural provisions for enacting a joint resolution involve Congress adopting and transmitting it to the President within a specified timeframe after receiving an affirmative determination from the Commission. During a 5-year period, Congress must adopt and transmit a joint resolution to the President within a specified timeframe after receiving an affirmative determination from the Commission. If the President vetoes the resolution, both Houses of Congress must vote to override the veto within a set timeframe. The joint resolution must be introduced within 90 days of receiving an affirmative determination from the Commission. Any member of Congress can introduce the resolution in either House. Expedited procedures apply, subject to certain provisions. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to joint resolutions described in subsection (b) to the same extent as resolutions under such section. If a committee has not reported a joint resolution within 45 days of its introduction, the committee will be automatically discharged from further consideration of the resolution. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to joint resolutions described in subsection (b) to the same extent as resolutions under such section. If a committee has not reported a joint resolution within 45 days of its introduction, the committee will be automatically discharged from further consideration of the resolution. Joint resolutions must be reported by the Committee on Finance or Ways and Means before being considered by the Senate or House of Representatives. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to joint resolutions described in subsection (b) to the same extent as resolutions under such section. A joint resolution may only be made on the second legislative day after the calendar day on which the Member making the motion announces to the House his or her intention to do so. It shall not be in order in either the House of Representatives or the Senate to consider a joint resolution if that House has previously adopted a joint resolution under this section relating to the same matter. This section is enacted by the Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The rules of each House can supersede other rules if inconsistent, with the constitutional right to change rules at any time. SEC. 7. PARTICIPATION IN WTO PANEL PROCEEDINGS. In WTO panel proceedings, private US entities with a direct economic interest in the dispute resolution can participate if they support the US Government's position. The Trade Representative will ensure their full participation through regulations. Access to information will be provided to these entities by the Trade Representative. The Trade Representative will provide information from WTO dispute settlement proceedings to relevant parties and establish a protective order system for confidential information. Upon request, the Trade Representative will consult with and include these parties in the dispute settlement panel process. The Trade Representative will allow special delegation members with special knowledge to appear before the dispute settlement panel through counsel under US Government supervision, especially in cases involving confidential information. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Appellate Body," "adverse to the United States," "dispute settlement panel," and "Dispute Settlement Body." The Act defines key terms related to dispute settlement, including the Dispute Settlement Body, Dispute Settlement Understanding, Uruguay Round Agreement, World Trade Organization (WTO), and WTO Agreement. The term "WTO Agreement" refers to the Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization signed on April 15, 1994.
